content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a large section of colonic wall with an associated tumor. The intensely basophilic (dark purple) area on the lower left represents the adenocarcinoma, which appears to be large and fungating. The tumor seems to be deeply invasive, extending through the colonic wall (pink layers) and into the adjacent pericolic adipose tissue (pale, web-like area on the right). There are a few smaller, separate tissue fragments that could represent lymph nodes. The primary task on this slide would be to determine the depth of invasion for T-staging.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

This area is the most critical for staging the primary tumor. The green box is placed at the interface between the main tumor mass and the outer layers of the bowel wall, representing the deepest point of invasion or the 'leading edge' of the tumor. Examining this specific location allows me to assess whether the tumor is confined to the muscularis propria (T2) or has invaded through it into the subserosal/pericolic soft tissues (T3), which is a crucial prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, there is a clear demarcation between two tissue types. The lower portion is heavily infiltrated by malignant glandular cells, consistent with adenocarcinoma. These tumor cells are characterized by large, hyperchromatic nuclei and are associated with a dense inflammatory and desmoplastic stromal reaction. The upper portion consists of thick, eosinophilic bundles of smooth muscle, which represents the muscularis propria. The adenocarcinoma is unequivocally seen infiltrating and disrupting these smooth muscle bundles. This finding confirms invasion into the muscularis propria, making the tumor at least a T2 stage. I would continue to scan along this invasive front to determine if there is extension beyond the muscularis propria into the pericolic fat.
